Posts.Content: On 10/17/2007 annalittlebit wrote: I was diagnosed with breast cancer in 2003--I underwent surgery for one breast, chemo and radiation. I have been taking arimidex since. Although I try not to dwell on the possibility of recurrance I find that sometimes I worry a great deal about the cancer coming back.  I also think at times that I want to stop arimidex due to the side affects which I live with daily. Does anyone have input to , or share my concerns??  Please respond. I just stumbled upon this website this morning and am hoping it is a good place to be.  Friends who have not shared my experience cannot relate to my feelings on these matters. I was diagnosed with invasive ductal carcinoma 2 years ago.  My husband had just finished horrendous chemotherapy for a retroperitoneal liposarcoma, so I knew something about cancer treatment.  My nodes were clear, tumor was estrogen receptor positive, and I had the Oncotype DX test done to determine my risk of recurrence.  To my dismay, I am at high risk for recurrence (evidently a very nasty tumor), so I underwent dose dense CAT chemo and radiation, then started Arimidex, which I have been on for 15 months now.  The muscle and joint pain is still bad, but not as much as the first year.  I have to take two other prescription meds for the debilitating hot flashes (Effexor and Megace).  My hands shake so much I can hardly write clearly.  Even the computer is hard.  I have terrible insomnia.  But I feel like I am FIGHTING!!!!  Our last Christmas card motto was "The ultimate in togetherness is sharing the same oncologist."  Four months ago my husband died; he had started chemo again and two weeks later he was gone.  His heart had been weakened by the previous chemo, and just gave out.  I saw him fight valiently until the very end, and my kids and grandkids saw him as such a great example.  He worked full time until the last month of his life.  I want to be the same way--do whatever I have to do to fight this horrific disease until it either gets me or I die of old age.  The thought of recurrence I think is in the mind of anyone who has had cancer.  But if the nasty Arimidex will help me ward off this demon for longer, I'll do it.  If my oncologist recommends switching to another drug, I will also do that. Just keep fighting, and know you are not alone, as all these other messages have indicated.    Jo Ellen

Posts.Content: I just gave my experience on another message, but my hot flashes were also unbearable.  Same sleep problems, and I wanted to rip my clothes off in public, I was so hot!  I would also just get feeling sick and nauseated.   My oncologist had me try Effexor XR, which helped only a tiny bit.  I then stopped that and tried Megace.  It also helped a little bit.  The doctor then had me take both Effexor and Megace together, and I finally got some relief.  It doesn't completely eradicate the flashes, but they are much less severe and less frequent.  It had made a big difference in my quality of life.    Hope something works for you.  Good luck,  Jo Ellen
Posts.Title: NEVER ENDING HOT FLASHES !?!?!?!?

Posts.Content: I had a lumpectomy for invasive ductal carcinoma of the left breast(negative nodes), followed by dose dense CAT and then radiation for 7 weeks (finished that 7 weeks ago) and am now on Arimidex. A few days ago I noticed a soreness/tenderness on my left chest wall on the same side as radiation. It does not involve the underarm area, but is about 2 inches lower down. I'm hoping it is just a passing side effect of radiation, and not something more serious (like cancer in my ribs now!) Has anyone else experienced lateral chest discomfort like this? thanks.
